docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Jacob Haas, an eclectic physician with a lucrative practice on the east side, had planned to marry his niece. Fannie Thaller, on June 7. Miss Thaller's parents objected to the marriage, and the laws of the State prevent an uncle from marrying his niece, but the couple had arranged to elope to Providence, R.I. At least that is what Miss Thaller, says, and the story is corroborated by friends of Dr. Haas.

They said it was probable that more raids would be undertaken during the night.

docs.abstract: Law enforcement officials attending 3-day public hearing by NJ Investigations Comm into narcotics operations within state on Dec 18 identify Cuban narcotics ring, operating between Miami and northern NJ, as 'prime source' of cocaine for NY met area; say couriers, including women concealing drug in 'false pregnancies' and padded bras, transport drug into Fla from S Amer, Mex and Brit and French possessions and carry it north to Cuban population centers where it is sold to entrepreneurs who distribute it through normal drug channels; Dade County, Fla, narcotics official A Richards says illicit drug traffic in Fla is largely controlled by well-organized Cuban and black orgns; says orgns have no drug importation capabilities but rely on Cuban contacts for all their cocaine and for some heroin; says Cuban orgns 'operate on a clannish basis, the hierarchy being composed of relatives or long-time proven relationships,' adding that 'infiltration by either American operatives or unfamiliar Latins has proven unsuccessful; Exec Dir M G Holleran says large shipments of cocaine have been transported to northern states hidden in side panels of automobiles, on bodies of couriers or carried brazenly in attache cases; says greater cooperation among county, state and Fed officials presently is producing kind of intelligence necessary to crack down effectively on wide-ranging narcotics operations; NYC Asst Dist Atty Rogers says NYC's drug dealers may begin transferring their operations across state lines when weight of new NYS narcotics law is fully appreciated; mentions Ft Lee (NJ) and Greenwich (Conn) as likely resettlement areas for NY drug dealers because of their proximity to city; Richards and Hudson County, NJ, law enforcement official J J Hill Jr illus at hearing

headline.main: Abbie Hoffman Fights Defining of Cocaine as Narcotic; Before Sept. 1

docs.abstract: A Hoffman, former antiwar activist who was arrested with 3 other persons on Aug 28 while attempting to sell cocaine to undercover narcotics agent, on Nov 14 files arguments in NYS Sup Ct seeking to have charges dismissed on ground that cocaine has been misclassified in state law as narcotic drug; atty for Hoffman maintains cocaine should be classified with amphetamines, both chemically and 'in their effects,' and that person convicted of charges similar to those facing Hoffman would face maximum prison term of 7 yrs; NYC special narcotics prosecutor F J Rogers contends classification of cocaine with narcotic drugs, such as heroin, is 'a rational one' and does not abridge defendants' rights; cites Fed statistics, adding that it is irrelevant that cocaine 'is not a narcotic in the strict medical sense'; bolsters argument with statement from NYC Chief Med Examiner M J Helpern, who maintains that 'there is ample evidence to prove that cocaine is a harmful, dangerous, addictive drug' that should not be available to the public; Helpern maintains arguments that cocaine is 'not harmful because it is not a narcotic is fallacious'; motion to have case dismissed because of misclassification of cocaine as a narcotic is supported by affidavits from persons with professional experience in drug field-most of whom have been associated with efforts to liberalize marijuana laws; Hoffman illus

docs.lead_paragraph: Abbie Hoffman, a counterculture leader of the 1960's who jumped bail in 1974 after being charged with selling cocaine, surrendered yesterday to law-enforcement authorities in Manhattan. He was then released on his own recognizance after his lawyer told a judge that Mr. Hoffman had become a ''hero'' in the remote upstate community where he had been living. Sterling Johnson Jr., the state's special narcotics prosecutor, had recommended a $100,000 bond or cash bail of $10,000. The charges involve the alleged sale of three pounds of cocaine to undercover police officers for $36,000, punishable in case of conviction by 15 years to life imprisonment.

docs.lead_paragraph: Abbie Hoffman, the 43-year-old former Yippie and antiwar activist who has been a fugitive for six years, said yesterday that he planned to surrender to Federal authorities here this morning after living for the last four years on a tiny upstate New York island under the alias Barry Freed. Mr. Hoffman said in an interview in the Manhattan office of a friend that he had instructed his lawyer, Gerald B. Lefcourt, to arrange his surrender on a 1974 charge that he had sold cocaine to undercover policemen. It was during pretrial hearings in that case that Mr. Hoffman, fearing that he faced possible conviction and a long prison term, decided to go underground.

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Evans, the producer of such movies as ''The Godfather,'' ''Serpico'' and ''Urban Cowboy,'' pleaded guilty in New York City yesterday to possession of cocaine. His brother, Charles, and a brother-in-law, Michael Shure, who were charged with him, also pleaded guilty. John H. Martin, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, said the cocaine was bought by Charles Evans from an undercover narcotics agent on May 2. Robert Evans was in California at the time, but the authorities said he had agreed in a telephone conversation with his brother to split the $19,000 cost of about five ounces of the drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: The neatly ridged and rowed patches of vegetation, etched into the flanks of virtually every mountain in this high-altitude region of Bolivia, look like game boards from a distance. Recently, they have been producing lots of winners. The steeply terraced fields yield coca leaves, and the leaves yield cocaine, the price of which, because of soaring worldwide demand, has increased threefold and more in the last five years.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Customs Service seized 500 pounds of cocaine last night from an airplane that landed on a deserted roadway in the Florida Panhandle after a four-hour, 400-mile chase off the coast. The seizure was the third largest on record by the Customs Service, and Federal drug authorities said initial tests showed the cocaine was of extremely high purity, with a street value of at least $36 million, based on a price of $73,600 to $250,000 a pound. The cocaine was found in seven duffle bags in an abandoned twinengine Piper Cheyenne on the grounds of a mansion in Mossey Head, Fla., near Eglin Air Force Base and about 50 miles northeast of Pensacola.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senior military officers here have been involved in extraordinarily lucrative drug trafficking and other corruption since the armed forces took power 13 months ago, according to foreign and Bolivian officials and two individuals with first-hand knowledge of the drug flow. Some officers have received millions of dollars for protecting traffickers or for trafficking themselves in the processed and semiprocessed cocaine leaving Bolivia, the source of most of the cocaine that reaches the United States, according to officials of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency. The junta now governing Bolivia stepped in three weeks ago when Gen. Luis Garcia Meza was forced to resign as President by a military rebellion, prompted in part by officers who had discovered the corruption. The junta has called for a ''return to morality,'' but two of its three members have themselves been charged with corruption in the past. U.S. Is Withholding Aid The Reagan Administration, meanwhile, is withholding appointing an Ambassador or giving the country badly needed economic aid because of the involvement of Government leaders in the cocaine traffic, Administration officials have said.

docs.lead_paragraph: The brazen daylight assassinations of two judges and threats to kill 11 more have jolted Medellin, Colombia's second largest city and the country's traditional center of industry, hard work and thrift, into the realization that it has fallen under the influence of narcotics traffickers. ''Everyone thought the drug dealers were just up on the Atlantic coast, but they've arrived here now,'' said Juan Fernandez Carasquilla, president of the Criminal Court. ''Medellin used to be a staging area, but now there are laboratories all over the city and it has become our domestic industry.'' To the visitor, this city of 1.2 million has the vibrancy of a onetime frontier town sure of its up-to-date importance. Men in rolled brim hats, cowboy boots and open-neck shirts mix comfortably on its broad streets with the business-suited executives who toil in the sleek skyscrapers that have risen over midtown.

AMONG THOSE IS FAVOR OF ACTION ON THE BILL ARE THOSE WHO SUPPORT INCREASED MILITARY SALES TO ISRAEL. THE $1.4 BILLION IN MILITARY SALES CREDITS SUBMITTED BY THE ADMINISTRATION FOR ISRAEL MAY BE INCREASED BY $200 MILLION, LEGISLATIVE SOURCES SAID. THE APPROPRIATION BILL FOR FINANCING FOREIGN AID FOR THE CURRENT FISCAL YEAR WAS SCUTTLED LAST WEEK BY THE DEMOCRATIC LEADERSHIP IN THE HOUSE WHEN INFORMAL TALKS WITH REPUBLICANS INDICATED THAT THE REQUESTED FUNDS WOULD RISK SHARP CUTBACKS IN A FLOOR DEBATE. FINANCING WILL BE PROVIDED BY A CONTINUNG RESOLUTION MAINTAINING THE SAME LEVEL OF AID FOR THE COMING YEAR AS DURING FISCAL 1980, WITH A FEW AMENDMENTS. AMENDMENTS THAT ARE EXPECTED TO BE PROPOSED AT A SENATE-HOUSE CONFERENCE ON A CONTINUING RESOLUTION WOULD INCLUDE ADDITIONAL MILITARY SALES CREDITS TO ISRAEL AND MORE MONEY FOR REFUGEE PROGRAMS THAT PUT A BURDEN ON LOCAL COMMUNITIES, SUCH AS THE SETTLING OF CUBAN AND HAITIAN REFUGEES IN FLORIDA. byline.original: By WARREN HOGE, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Cocaine, the drug of choice for dealers, entertainers and the well-to-do seeking a powerful recreational drug with comparatively few dangers, is sending more and more users to the emergency room or the morgue, according to statistics that are emerging around the country. Although cocaine is not a leading cause of drug-related deaths, in a number of cities, including bellwether San Francisco and New York, it is now the fastest-growing source of serious drug-related medical problems, according to epidemiologists for the National Institute on Drug Abuse who met last week in Washington. Behind the surge in health problems appears to be a growing tendency for users of the very expensive drug to take large doses in search of what the author William Burroughs called ''a rush of pure pleasure to the head.'' These doses are taken either by injecting the substance, like heroin, or by smoking a highly concentrated and chemically altered form called ''freebase,'' made by treating the white powder with ether.

headline.main: HEAVY USE OF COCAINE IS LINKED TO SURGE IN DEATHS AND ILLNESSES

byline.original: By WAYNE KING, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: A special task force of Federal drug agents and New York City and State police has uncovered and disrupted a nationwide ring of cocaine smugglers said to be among the country's top suppliers of the drug. Their investigation, officials say, is one of the first to penetrate the tightly knit world of Colombian narcotics trafficking, a world in which a rigid code of silence is enforced by murder. The task force's work has taken three years, and it is continuing. ''This investigation represented one of the most significant enforcement operations ever undertaken, because of the size, scope, sophistication and impact of the smuggling ring,'' said Peter B. Bensinger, outgoing head of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration. Mr. Bensinger, who established the investigation, is going to be removed by President Reagan, according to Justice Department officials, who said Friday that he had lobbied against budget cuts proposed for his agency. Imports Worth $200 Million a Year The case, which began three years ago with an unexceptional arrest on a quiet street in Queens, led agents to Miami, Atlanta, Baltimore, Tucson, Ariz., and Philadelphia and interdicted a conspiracy that used bogus companies to import pure cocaine worth at least $200 million a year, according to law enforcement authorities. In the course of it, the agents seized an arsenal of weapons ranging from delicate silver derringers to rifles with telescopic sights and machine guns equipped with silencers.

Under state law, Mr. Hoffman must serve a year before becoming eligible for parole.

The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, said that cocaine had become so irresistible to the middle class that he predicted its use would no longer be thought of as against the law. ''That's what happened with marijuana,'' said Mr. Merola. ''And it may happen with cocaine in the next decade, in spite of the fact that medical testimony shows cocaine to be extremely dangerous. What happens with drugs is that when we cannot deal with them, we attempt to legalize them. It's wrong.''

byline.original: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The use of illicit drugs in Hollywood has become so pervasive that companies that insure movies have begun to amend their policies to reflect drug-related risks, and some people in the entertainment industry maintain that drug abuse is affecting the content and quality of films and television programs produced here. Police investigators in Los Angeles contend that cocaine and other drugs are sold routinely on many film and television production sets. Drug dealers, some of them riding in chauffeured limousines, make regular rounds to the homes of executives, performers and technicians in the film, television and rock music industries, some of whom are spending as much as $1 million a year on cocaine. Grand Jury Investigates Federal agents allege that William Morgan Hetrick, who was indicted Friday on cocaine trafficking charges with John Z. De Lorean, the former executive of the General Motors Corporation, was among the major suppliers of cocaine to the Hollywood entertainment industry before his arrest. Mr. Hetrick, who has denied complicity in any illicit drug dealing, is a 50-year-old former resident of Ventura County who was a pilot and operator of a three-plane flying service at a small-town airport in the Mojave Desert.

They said they hoped other doctors would become aware of the potential hazard of the drug, which is widely used as a surface anesthetic.

docs.lead_paragraph: The huge profits to be found in cocaine trafficking are luring more and more middle-class and upper-income Americans to the cocaine trade, law-enforcement officials say, and relatively few of them are being caught. Although no one knows how much money is involved, the United States Drug Enforcement Administration estimates that more than $30 billion is spent annually by cocaine users in this country. The smuggling and distribution of the drug, officials say, are largely controlled by Colombians and other Latin Americans, as well as organized crime in this country. But they say the trade is so lucrative, the chances of being caught are so small and the use of the drug has become so acceptable in some segments of American society that it is increasingly attracting dealers from middle-class professional and business life. ''It's greed,'' said Charles Palmer, a senior Drug Enforcement Administration agent in San Francisco. ''Cocaine is a multibilliondollar industry, and it's polluting all levels of society, from the lower classes to the very affluent. The affluent are going into it because there are such incredible amounts of money.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A convicted cocaine distributor and his son were indicted today on charges of conspiring to murder five persons involved in the cocaine case, including the Federal judge who sentenced the father. Jose Robert Gomez Soto, 57 years old, and his son, Peter Gomez, 24, are accused of soliciting two convicts to kill Federal District Judge Robert P. Aguilar, who presided over the older Mr. Gomez's trial for conspiracy to import and distribute cocaine. Mr. Gomez was convicted May 20, 1982, and is serving a 20-year sentence in the Federal prison at Lompoc, Calif. Other targets of the plot, according to the indictment, were Assistant United States Attorney William S. Farmer, who prosecuted Mr. Gomez; Lowrey Leong, an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration; Stephen Green, Mr. Gomez's son-in-law and a convicted cocaine dealer who cooperated with the Government investigation, and Bobby Sharp, who is reportedly cooperating with the authorities while awaiting trial on drug charges.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Walter Riker, the medical consultant to the National Football League on drug abuse and a leading expert on the effects of cocaine on athletes, says he can spot the strung-out players on his television screen any Sunday afternoon in the fall. One looks much too tired, as he is barely able to walk off the field when the ball changes hands. Then the camera takes in the sideline, and Dr. Riker spots a player on the bench. He is much too jittery at this point in the game, his legs beating a staccato on the planking beneath him. Dr. Riker begins to suspect the worst. For Carl Eller of the Minnesota Vikings, one of the most intimidating defensive ends, five times an all-pro, it is the worst. Glaring at him from the other side of the scrimmage line was Claudie Minor, an offensive tackle for the Denver Broncos whom Eller said he had dominated for years. But now Minor was making him look bad.

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials of the National Football League warned yesterday that the use of cocaine had become so widespread among its players that it now posed a threat to the continued integrity of the game. Charles S. Jackson, the league's assistant director of security and drug abuse and a former undercover narcotics agent for the Yonkers Police Department, said he doubted that cocaine use had reached epidemic levels, as some officials fear. He said there was ''absolutely no evidence thus far'' that gambling interests had succeeded in using cocaine to corrupt the game. But he also said that ''the longer the problem of cocaine continues to grow, the greater the chance of it occurring.'' Mr. Jackson and other league officials said that only 17 players had been identified as ''chemically dependent'' on cocaine. But Mr. Jackson said in an interview that ''it was quite possible'' that as many as 40 to 50 players in the league had a ''chemical dependency on the drug'' and that hundreds of the league's 1,500 players were using it, many of them regularly.

docs.lead_paragraph: A fifth person was arrested yesterday in connection with the seizure on Thursday of 610 pounds of pure cocaine in an airdrop smuggling operation on Long Island. Charles E. Rose, an assistant United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, identified the most recent suspect as John O'Neill, the 40-year-old operator of the Westhampton Airport, who lives at 202 Hillrise Avenue in Calverton in Suffolk County. Mr. Rose said Mr. O'Neill filled up illegal extra fuel tanks in the airplane that was purportedly used by the other suspects to smuggle the cocaine - said by United States Customs Service officials to have a street value of $200 million - from Colombia in South America.

docs.lead_paragraph: George Rogers, the National Football League's leading rusher, and Dave Wilson, one of his teammates on the Saints, have told a Federal grand jury in New Orleans that as rookies last season they purchased and used cocaine, according to Justice Department officials here. Rogers, the officials said, testified that he spent more than $10,000 on the drug. Both men are reported to have said that the seller was Mike Strachan, a former member of the Saints whom the grand jury has already indicted on charges of cocaine trafficking. His trial is scheduled to begin next Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 100 Federal, state and local law enforcement officers staked out near a runway at Brookhaven Airport before dawn today watched as 610 pounds of pure cocaine in duffel bags were shoved out of a plane. They later arrested four men on charges of drug trafficking. The plane, a twin-engined Cessna Titan 404 arriving from Colombia, landed at 3:45 A.M. and dropped eight duffel bags containing packages of cocaine in plastic bags, gift wrap and newspapers before taking off again. The duffel bags, whose contents have been estimated by officials as having a street value of $200 million, were picked up at the end of the field by three men who dragged them through a wooded area and loaded them on a station wagon that was then driven off.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fourteen pounds of cocaine with a street value of $4.5 million have been seized from a Colombian cargo ship tied up in Brooklyn, the Customs Service said yesterday. A Customs Service spokesman, Michael Kaufman, said the cocaine was found in the engine room of the Ciudad de Pasto during a routine search Tuesday afternoon by customs agents and investigators from the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration. No arrests were made in connection with the cocaine seizure, he said, adding that three stowaways who were discovered on the ship were turned over to immigration authorities.

docs.lead_paragraph: The rate of cocaine-related deaths quadrupled from 1976 to 1981 while the rate of cocaine-related hospital treatment showed a sixfold increase from 1975 to 1981, the Federal Centers for Disease Control reported today. The Federal health agency, citing a report by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, also said that nearly 10 million people over 11 years old reported using cocaine in 1978-79, more than double the number of users the previous year. The agency's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report cited figures compiled by the Drug Abuse Warning Network showing that the number of deaths linked to cocaine increased from 4.5 per 10,000 medical examiner reports to 19.1 deaths per 10,000 reports from 1976 to 1981.

docs.lead_paragraph: Already fighting a myriad of problems, Yankee players were upset yesterday when they learned that some members of the team had been mentioned as cocaine users in a wiretapped conversation between two defendants in a narcotics case. Justice Burton Roberts of State Supreme Court in Manhattan declared a mistrial in the case yesterday afternoon because three persons who had been selected for the jury, and others who were prospective jurors, had read a newspaper article about the mention of the Yankees. Justice Roberts rescheduled the trial for June 1. The conversation was first disclosed Wednesday when Justice Roberts, while questioning prospective jurors, told them that ''the names of one or more of the New York Yankees'' were on the tape and asked them whether this would influence them in deciding the case.

docs.lead_paragraph: Alarmed by the popularity of cocaine and the deaths that have accompanied its abuse, New York State took a step yesterday toward devising a uniform statewide strategy for helping users of the drug. About 250 people, most of them state employees, were brought together in New York City by the Division of Substance Abuse Services to hear medical and legal experts, as well as government officials from around the country, discuss problems stemming from the use of cocaine. After their two-day meeting ends this afternoon, the participants are to recommend ways in which the state might arrive at a specific treatment program for cocaine users.

docs.lead_paragraph: John Belushi died because of an overdose of heroin and cocaine administered intravenously, the Los Angeles County Coroner's office announced today. Ending six days of speculation that began when the body of the 33-year-old actor was found Friday in a Hollywood hotel, Dr. Thomas T. Noguchi, the coroner, released his findings in a three-sentence statement. ''The medical investigation into the death of John Belushi has been completed,'' Dr. Noguchi said. ''The deceased died of an overdose due to intravenous injections of heroin and cocaine. Both cocaine and heroin were found on the premises.''

The Los Angeles Times reported today that a source in the coroner's office had said that Mr. Belushi died of complications from an overdose of cocaine. A local television station, KABC, gave a similar report, quoting a source identified only as close to the coroner's office. According to medical specialists on the abuse of drugs, excessive doses of cocaine can be fatal, although such deaths have been relatively rare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Vida Blue, one of baseball's most successful pitchers of the 1970's, pleaded guilty today to a Federal misdemeanor charge of possessing three grams, about a tenth of an ounce, of cocaine. A short time later, he appeared before a Federal grand jury hearing evidence in a six-month-old narcotics investigation here. The plea by the 34-year-old Blue brought to four the number of current or former Kansas City Royal players linked to the narcotics inquiry. Blue was released by the Royals on Aug. 1 after pitching ineffectively this year. Willie Wilson, Willie Aikens and Jerry Martin, all of whom finished the season with the Royals, pleaded guilty last week to another Federal misdemeanor charge, attempting to possess cocaine.

Each player was released on a $5,000 personal recognizance bond, and sentencing was set for Nov. 17. Amanda Meers, an assistant United States attorney, said Wilson and Aikens had been heard, in telephone calls ''intercepted by the F.B.I.,'' trying to make a cocaine purchase. Specifically, she said that on June 18, Wilson ''made a call to a residence in Johnson County for the purpose of obtaining one-fourth ounce of cocaine.''

docs.lead_paragraph: ''THE COCAINE CARTEL,'' an ''ABC Closeup'' documentary, saves its most fascinating material for the end. Carlos Lehder, who is wanted by United States authorities for his part in the drug traffic, is addressing a political rally in Colombia, denouncing his country's extradition treaty with the United States as a trick. A moment later, in an interview, he says that in resisting extradition he is ''fighting for the rights of my people.'' It is an interesting commentary on politics and international crime. The documentary will be seen tomorrow night at 10 on Channel 7. The documentary's principal interest lies in what it calls ''the new Mafia,'' the dozen or so Colombian families, or organizations, which it identifies as the managers of the cocaine trade. One Colombian, Pablo Escobar, is reported to be worth nearly $2 billion. He is said to own several ranches, a zoo and a small fleet of planes and helicopters. He is also said to have financed free housing for the poor. In a brief interview, Mr. Escobar defends the use of ill- gotten money.

docs.lead_paragraph: Players and former players involved with illegal drugs are hardly something new to the Dallas Cowboys. In 1972, before what would have been his third season at Dallas, Duane Thomas pleaded guilty of marijuana possession and was given a five-year probated sentence; three months later he was traded to the San Diego Chargers. In 1973, Lance Rentzel, a former Cowboy wide receiver, also pleaded guilty of possession of marijuana, and was sentenced to 90 days in jail. In 1978, four years after his retirement, Bob Hayes, a former wide receiver, was convicted of selling cocaine; he was sentenced to five years in prison, though he served less than one. John Niland, a guard from 1966 to 1974, will soon be tried in Dallas on charges of cocaine possession.

docs.lead_paragraph: Commissioner Pete Rozelle's four-game suspension of four National Football League players because of their involvement with cocaine received generally favorable reaction from various sectors of the league's community yesterday, including the N.F.L. Players Association. However, the St. Louis Cardinals and E.J. Junior, the Cardinal linebacker who pleaded guilty to cocaine-possession charges earlier this year in Alabama, were investigating the possibility of appealing the suspension to the league office. ''I don't know if we have the standing to appeal,'' Bob Wallace, a Cardinals club attorney, said from St. Louis. ''We're still discussing it. The suspension came without warning; it was sort of a surprise to us. The club had been happy with everything E.J. has done from the point of his arrest. We felt that he had taken what we considered were the proper steps toward rehabilitation.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Four National Football League players, including two members of the Cincinnati Bengals, were suspended without pay yesterday through the fourth game of the coming regular season by Commissioner Pete Rozelle, who cited their violation of league drug policies involving use of cocaine. The four players are Ross Browner, a defensive lineman for the Bengals; Pete Johnson, a Bengal fullback; E.J. Junior, a linebacker for the St. Louis Cardinals, and Greg Stemrick, a cornerback recently acquired by the New Orleans Saints from the Houston Oilers. ''After thoroughly reviewing the respective cases and meeting with the players and their representatives,'' the commissioner said in a harshly worded statement, ''I have determined that each player, due to his participation in illegal activities involving cocaine, will be suspended without pay through the fourth game of the 1983 regular season. None of the four players is permitted to attend training camp, practice sessions, meetings or otherwise use club facilities. All four will be eligible to petition for reinstatement following the fourth game of the '83 regular season.''

The officials said that the four players had been mentioned on an F.B.I. wiretap as users of small quantities of cocaine and that their lawyers had since been negotiating, and perhaps plea-bargaining, with the authorities. It could not be determined whether the players had been named or heard on the wiretap. Tex Schramm, the Cowboys' president, said that he was unaware the players had been implicated as users but that he had been informed by the National Football League's security office that they had been named in an investigation and had ''volunteered to give whatever help they could.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A Colombian lawyer and a former member of that nation's consulate in Hamburg, West Germany, were arrested yesterday in what officials said was a ''high level'' international cocaine trafficking conspiracy. The arrest of the lawyer, Carlos Nader-Simmonds of Bogota, and the former consulate official, G. Bocanegra-Cote, came just days before the scheduled shipment from Colombia to Miami of 22 pounds of cocaine valued at $400,000, authorities said. Mr. Nader, who is a member of Colombia's House of Representatives, was ordered held in $2 million bail by Magistrate Leonard Bernikow in Federal District Court in Manhattan. docs.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY THE tall young man is speaking softly now, so his words can hardly be heard. But the words come quickly because he is eager to tell his story. ''Hi, I'm John,'' he says, ''and I'm a drug addict.'' With that simple phrase, John Drew introduces himself on this day - and every other one - to the other addicts at a gathering of Alcoholics Anonymous, which also counsels drug addicts. He is addicted to cocaine, and has been, he says, ever since he began freebasing, which involves cooking the drug until it reaches its purest form, three years ago. He'd snorted it for two years before that. ''I tried something, and liked it,'' he says. ''And by liking it, it almost destroyed me.'' It came very close to destroying his career in pro basketball. Last Nov. 22, at the beginning of Drew's ninth National Basketball Association season - his first with the Utah Jazz - he received a telephone call at 7 A.M. while he was asleep in a hotel room in Cleveland. It was Dan Sparks, the team trainer.

docs.lead_paragraph: John Z. DeLorean was found not guilty by a Federal jury today of all eight counts of an indictment charging him with trafficking in millions of dollars worth of cocaine. Showing videotapes of Mr. DeLorean saying ''I want to proceed'' with a drug deal, and in the end accepting a suitcase with 55 pounds of cocaine, the Government had sought to depict him as a venal, ego-driven businessman trying to save his British-American automobile company through the sale of narcotics. The trial lasted 22 weeks. Jurors Saw Entrapment But some of the jurors said the Government had failed to prove its case; others said the undercover investigation had sometimes slipped over the line into entrapment. The verdict cleared Mr. DeLorean of all the drug charges. The Government cannot appeal the acquittal.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Government's most important cocaine eradication program, in a valley between the Andes and the Peruvian jungles, has been suspended because of a wave of guerrilla raids in the area, United States officials say. The guerrillas are members of the Shining Path movement, who say they are fighting to impose a Chinese-style political system in Peru. In recent weeks, they have killed local policemen, attacked the installations of United States and Peruvian Government employees and routed the United States-trained narcotics strike force in Peru's cocaine-growing region and its center, Tingo Maria, a town 340 miles northeast of the Peruvian capital. Many Workers Withdrawn Many workers in the $30 million program in the area around Tingo Maria were withdrawn late last month, United States officials said in interviews last week, and efforts to destroy coca fields and the program to create alternative crops have been halted.

It also said a Nicaraguan Government official had been encouraging smugglers to begin using a new cocaine laboratory recently built in Nicaragua. The Nicaraguan official said he wanted the smugglers to begin flying cocaine base from Bolivia to Nicaragua, where cocaine would be manufactured and then would be flown to the United States, the affidavit said.

They are clean-cut, ambitious students headed for Ivy League colleges. With their allowances, they buy cocaine and they ''party'' on weekends, sometimes in their rooms at their exclusive Massachusetts preparatory school and sometimes in the discotheques of New York or Boston. ''It used to be such a big thing to have it,'' says a 16-year-old girl. ''Now everyone's so blase.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Coca leaf plantations and cocaine laboratories have been found for the first time in the vast jungles of the Amazon basin, according to United States and Brazilian officials here. The cocaine trade's move into the Brazilian lowlands from its traditional havens in the Andean mountains of Bolivia, Peru and Colombia is a major expansion of the drug network supplying the United States, the officials said. They added that cocaine operators were active in the Amazon region before Colombia and Peru began their largest antidrug campaigns ever this month, but they suggested that diversification into Brazil may have been planned in anticipation of tougher enforcement. As the Brasilia Government is beginning to recognize the potential dimensions of its narcotics problems, it has been in touch with Colombia and Peru to coordinate regional police efforts. A meeting of representatives of the three countries is planned here next week.

Weitzman, asserted that the 59-year-old chairman of the DeLorean Motor Company was pushed to that point by a Government setup and asked news organizations to examine the Government's tactics. "Clearly his judgment was not only poor, it was nonexistant," Mr. Weitzman said of Mr. DeLorean, who sat sober-faced but silent nearby. "It's very clear that John DeLorean referred to cocaine when he was talking about 'monkeys'," Mr. Weitzman told a score of reporters covering the automaker's trial on charges that he conspired to import 55 pounds of cocaine. docs.lead_paragraph: Senior Reagan Administration officials say the United States is losing a critical battle in the war on drugs, the fight to stop airborne smuggling of cocaine. For Federal investigators, cocaine has become the top-priority drug, and official estimates indicate nearly half the country's supply is smuggled from Latin America aboard small, private aircraft. The Customs Service is responsible for interdicting those flights, which may have numbered nearly 18,000 last year. But in 1983, Customs estimates indicate, the air program probably intercepted only one smuggler's flight of every 100. Meanwhile, R. T. McNamar, Deputy Treasury Secretary, and Customs Commissioner William von Raab, say they have decided that the service, a part of the Treasury Department, should no longer be responsible for the key element in the airborne drug war: detecting the aircraft.

docs.lead_paragraph: AN extensive new survey indicates that the use of cocaine continues to increase dramatically in the United States and that the problems associated with it are far worse than many people had believed. These conclusions are drawn by researchers who have interviewed or talked briefly with thousands of callers on a ''cocaine helpline,'' a telephone service set up to offer advice to the nation's five million cocaine users and to people asking questions about cocaine-related problems. The researchers now report receiving about 1,000 calls a day nationwide. Medical and social difficulties appear to be particularly acute among people who take the drug intranasally - that is, by inhaling it through the nose. About half of the people interviewed who said they took the drug intranasally reported feelings of paranoia and panic, considered themselves to be addicted and experienced withdrawal symptoms when they stopped using cocaine.

docs.lead_paragraph: In response to changing patterns of drug abuse, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has embarked on a new agenda in New York and stepped up the pursuit of organizations trafficking in cocaine, according to the newly appointed head of the agency's largest district office. ''That doesn't mean we're denigrating heroin, but it's not the only problem anymore and so we have to change our priorities,'' said Robert M. Stutman, special agent in charge of the agency's office in New York. Mr. Stutman six weeks ago replaced Bruce M. Jensen, who retired. In November, according to Mr. Stutman, 2,200 pounds of cocaine were seized by the agency in the metropolitan region, most of it during raids in Long Island and New Jersey suburbs. While large seizures are not a measure of the agency's success, Mr. Stutman said, the size of the recent raids is one indication of the growing cocaine problem.

Fox, a 47-year-old entrepreneur, socialite and the chairman of Iroquois Brands, has cast a cloud of uncertainty over the career of one of the New York area's more successful businessmen. Mr. Fox, whose Greenwich-based company is one of the nation's largest makers of liquor, specialty foods and vitamins, was arrested here Nov. 6. He and Barbara Phelan, a 38-year-old Hartford resident, were escorted in handcuffs from a Hartford hotel suite where the police said they found 17 grams of cocaine and drug paraphernalia. Both Mr. Fox and Miss Phelan have pleaded not guilty. Richard Brown, a Hartford attorney who is representing them, filed a motion Monday in Hartford Superior Court to have the charges dismissed on the ground that the police had insufficient evidence to enter and search Mr. Fox's hotel room. Mr. Fox has declined to be interviewed, and Mr. Brown said he would have no other statement on the case.

byline.original: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: A new form of cocaine is for sale on the streets of New York, alarming law-enforcement officials and rehabilitation experts because of its tendency to accelerate abuse of the drug, particularly among adolescents. The substance, known as crack, is already processed into the purified form that enables cocaine users to smoke, or free-base, the powerful stimulant of the central nervous system. Previously, free-basers had to reduce cocaine powder themselves to its unadulterated form by combining it with baking soda or ether and evaporating the resulting paste over a flame. Since crack appeared on the streets of the Bronx last year, spreading throughout the city and its suburbs, new cocaine users have graduated more quickly from inhaling to free-basing, the most addictive form of cocaine abuse. In addition, dealers in crack have found a ready market in people reluctant to intensify their intake by intravenous injection of cocaine because of the fear of AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a fatal affliction that is spread by contaminated needles.

docs.lead_paragraph: A former Choate Rosemary Hall student who admitted smuggling cocaine from South America for his prep school classmates was sentenced today in Federal District Court to five years of probation and 5,000 hours of community service. Prosecutors had urged a prison term for the former student, Derek Oatis, who was arrested at Kennedy International Airport last year with 350 grams of cocaine and a list of Choate students who were financing the drug purchase. But after tearful pleas for leniency from Mr. Oatis's parents, Judge T. F. Gilroy Daly called a recess and returned moments later to announce that he had decided against a prison sentence. ''I'm not going to send you to jail,'' the judge told Mr. Oatis, ''but that is what I was prepared to do when I came here this morning.''

byline.original: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: THREE years ago the director of research and treatment at Regent Hospital in Manhattan, Dr. Arnold M. Washton, developed a curative program for cocaine abusers that he described as the first such specialized private drug-treatment program in New York City. Now he is duplicating that model here in Westchester, where, he says, there is considerable need for it. The program, consisting primarily of outpatient services, is conducted at The Recovery Center, affiliated with and located at Stony Lodge Hospital in Ossining, a private psychiatric hospital recently re-opened under new leadership. Dr. Washton is best known for his work with the National Cocaine Hotline, 800-COCAINE, which he helped to establish with Dr. Mark S. Gold. Dr. Gold is research director at Stony Lodge Hospital under the new team there. Apart from its specific focus on cocaine abuse, The Recovery Center will serve people who want help in stopping any kind of drug abuse. Treatment is now being offered as part of Dr. Washton's outpatient psychiatric practice; Dr. Washton said he hoped the program would obtain full licensing from the state, which would allow it to expand, in the coming months. He added he has already been ''swamped'' with county residents requesting help.

Marijuana use was down 3 percent, the study, the Drug Enforcement Agency said, mainly because fewer young people were using it. The agency's annual ''Narcotics Intelligence Estimate,'' a detailed analysis of drug use, supplies, trafficking and money in 1984, also said the most significant factor on the international cocaine market was the expansion of all phases of trafficking: cultivation, processing and distribution.

docs.lead_paragraph: PROFESSIONAL American athletes are today's highly paid folk heroes who live in a media-created fishbowl, the most recent one located in the Federal court building in Pittsburgh, where two trials focused attention on the extent of cocaine use in major league baseball. Our folk heroes have substituted clay feet for the customary spiked shoes. Enjoying an immunity from prosecution, they are freely disclosing their own past use of the drug, and in addition, pushing their buddies out of the cocaine closets around the country's ball parks. Even the venerable Willie Mays has been ''fingered'' by a former teammate. Do these confessions add up to a new drug scandal? Unhappily, I would have to answer yes. What we see in baseball today is the tip of the iceberg, part of an American cocaine epidemic of the 1980's. Perhaps the shocking spectacle of cocaine's infiltration into our national pastime will help prompt us to take drastic measures to stop the widespread use of the drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: The investigation of the parachutist who died when he hit the ground with a duffel bag of cocaine strapped to him has uncovered some unusual leads, and beyond that has drawn the public's attention to the the latest battlefield in the war on drugs, Federal agents say. The death of the parachutist, Andrew C. Thornton 2d, on Sept. 10 left a trail of evidence from Florida to the Tennessee mountains. Agents for the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration say the leads will probably result in the indictment of people suspected of awaiting delivery of the cocaine. The first lead came when the police found an address book in Mr. Thornton's belongings. The book had names and phone numbers that provided a guide to the investigators.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE afflictions of mankind are the issues on which nonfiction television - and all news organizations, for that matter - often do their best work. Sometimes the spreading of the word about a problem temporarily displaces others in the rush for public attention that will bring funds and governmental energies to bear on a solution. At the moment, the inquiry into the use of cocaine among baseball players has placed that particular mood-altering drug in the headlines. ''High on the Job,'' a documentary on Channel 5/WNEW-TV at 9 o'clock tonight, may be even more valuable than the articles that are full of famous names because it concentrates on the effect of cocaine on millions of Americans whose names are not household words. These people are known only to their disrupted families and to their fellow workers on jobs made more dangerous by their addiction.

docs.lead_paragraph: John Milner, a former member of the Pittsburgh Pirates, said in United States District Court today that he had purchased cocaine in the Pirates' clubhouse at Three Rivers Stadium during a game in 1980. Milner identified the supplier of the cocaine as Curtis Strong, a Philadelphia man being tried on 16 counts of cocaine distribution to major league players. Milner, 35 years old and now unemployed, followed six active players who testified that they had purchased cocaine from Strong in recent years. He was the first to say he had bought the drug in a baseball clubhouse. All seven players have received immunity from prosecution. Milner also said that Willie Mays kept a bottle of ''red juice,'' or amphetamine pills dissolved in liquid, in his locker when the two played for the Mets in the early 1970's. Mays, who was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 1979, retired after the 1973 season.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dave Parker of the Cincinnati Reds testified in United States District Court today that when he was a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates he arranged cocaine transactions between a Pittsburgh man and players on the Pirates, the Houston Astros and the Los Angeles Dodgers. Parker, who played for the Pirates from 1973 to 1983, when he signed as a free agent with the Reds, acknowledged under frequently intense questioning that he had used cocaine from 1976 to 1982. He also said he had made it possible for his ''primary supplier'' to get into the Pirates' clubhouse at Three Rivers Stadium and to fly on the same plane with the Pirates when they traveled to other cities so drugs could be delivered to him and other players in those cities. The players who bought and used the drug at 1980 meetings he arranged, Parker said, included Dusty Baker, Derrell Thomas and Steve Howe, who were with the Los Angeles Dodgers at the time, and Enos Cabell and J. R. Richard, who were with the Houston Astros then. In addition, Parker said he introduced some of his teammates on the Pirates to a drug dealer and claimed to have used cocaine with six current and former members of the Pirates.

docs.lead_paragraph: Keith Hernandez of the Mets, admitting for the first time publicly that he has used cocaine, told a United States District Court today how the drug was ''a demon in me'' and how it is ''the devil on this earth.'' The star first baseman, the second player to testify in a trial of a man accused of drug dealing, said that he used cocaine for three years, from July 1980 to June 1983, and that he played one game in 1980 under the influence of the drug. ''That was the year I was crazy the second half, the time of my greatest use,'' he said. The statements came 24 hours after Lonnie Smith, an outfielder with the Kansas City Royals, testified that five players, including Mr. Hernandez and Joaquin Andujar, the St. Louis Cardinals' star pitcher, had used cocaine. Mr. Hernandez, 31 years old, discussing his cocaine use as a member of the Cardinals, said he had used the drug with Mr. Smith, Mr. Andujar, Bernie Carbo and Lary Sorensen. He said that there were other players involved but that he could not recall their names.

docs.lead_paragraph: After years in which Peruvian authorities chose to ignore the fast-expanding cocaine business, the country's new President, Alan Garcia Perez, has ordered a frontal attack on the problem. Two weeks ago the police moved into a jungle area near the Colombian border and seized four cocaine-processing installations and adjacent airstrips. The raids were financed by the United States, and Colombian helicopters ferried Peruvian policemen to the site. But it was the Garcia administration that provided the crucial political decision to go ahead. Some officials and diplomats here believe that the police raids may mark a turning point for Peru as important as the crackdown in Colombia that followed the slaying of that country's Justice Minister, Rodrigo Lara Bonilla, by drug traffickers on April 30, 1984.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cocaine use among baseball players has been so pervasive in recent years that the drug's debilitating effects have tarnished individual performances, shortened careers and influenced the outcome of games and pennant races, club officials and players say. John McHale, president of the Montreal Expos, said cocaine was the reason his team did not win its division championship in 1982, when the team generally was considered to be the best in the National League. ''I don't think there's any doubt in '82 that whole scenario cost us a chance to win,'' McHale said. ''We felt we should've won in '82. When we all woke up to what was going on, we found there were at least eight players on our club who were into this thing. There's no question in my mind and Jim Fanning's mind - he was managing the club that year - that cost us a chance to win.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The use of cocaine by major league baseball players has been so widespread in recent years that scores of players have been implicated in criminal investigations as users, purchasers and, sometimes, as sellers of the drug. However, the players generally have not been prosecuted, and in some cases law enforcement officials have taken unusual steps to protect the players' identities. Court documents and interviews with more than 100 players, baseball executives and law-enforcement officials during a three-month investigation by The New York Times also uncovered the following facts: * Players representing nearly all 26 major league teams have been named in connection with cocaine use in criminal cases across the country, with some teams having several players named. * In at least four cities, drug dealers or their couriers had access to baseball clubhouses and conducted sales there. * The practice of shielding players from prosecution and identification has caused resentment among some defense lawyers, who feel that their clients have become scapegoats.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite improved vigilance by Federal and local agencies, more cocaine than ever is entering the United States, law-enforcement officials say. And they expect that improved smuggling strategies and unrelenting demand will keep the record-breaking flow coming. The officials said Miami was the center of cocaine traffic in this country, adding that about three-quarters of the cocaine intercepted nationwide last year was seized in the Florida-Caribbean district of the Drug Enforcement Administratioon. With a long coast and thousands of unused airstrips, south Florida has for years been the main point of entry of cocaine into the United States, which, according to recent statistics, has seen a dramatic increase in cocaine use at all social and economic levels. The officials, interviewed over several months, cited a shift from the use of large ships and airplanes for transporting cocaine to a wave of smaller boats and planes. They say this makes interception harder and, as one official said, ''overwhelms our interdiction resources.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Capital Cities Television Productions, the production arm of the company that will merge with ABC early next year, will produce an hour documentary on cocaine abuse in the work place, its chief of production said yesterday. The program, to be broadcast over a syndicated network in September, will be narrated by Stacy Keach, the actor recently released from Reading Prison in England after having served time for cocaine possession. Charlie Keller, the vice president and general manager of the unit, said that the documentary, ''High on the Job,'' was the latest in a series of 14 documentaries in which the company has tried to investigate social issues. The company's other current project is a dramatic series, ''Buchanan High School,'' which is being produced by the Rev. Ellwood Kieser of the Paulist Order of Priests.

docs.lead_paragraph: COCAINE being the drug of choice among the affluent, some of whom doubtless watch public television, it seems right that Channel 13 should take a look at the subject. This week it is devoting four hours to it - three documentaries done by Brian Moser and a panel discussion produced by Douglas Lutz. The project begins tonight at 10 with a remarkably close-in look at the processing and sale of the drug in its earlier stages. The hour combines anthropology, chemistry and human interest in an adventurous mix. The family referred to in the title ''Colombia: A Small Family Business'' is small all right - a man, his wife and their two sons - but their business has ramifications. Its head is Eliseo, who after a failed career as a rubber grower has staked out a patch of remote Colombian jungle to become a maker of cocaine - ''the most dangerous yet the most lucrative way of earning one's living.'' Eliseo is a pioneer, a trader, a scientist, a promoter, a philosopher. ''Here in the jungle I saw a freer life; it has no evil.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Clandestine cocaine laboratories in the New York area and Virginia, believed to be new bases for drug trafficking in the United States, were raided by law-enforcement authorities in the last two days, officials said yesterday. Ten Colombian nationals were arrested in the raids, and authorities seized large quantities of arms and chemicals used in converting cocaine base to cocaine, as well as sophisticated equipment used to monitor activity by the police and agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration. Officials said the laboratories indicated that cocaine traffickers had significantly changed their strategy by moving their manufacturing bases from Latin America to the United States. The raids were announced at the Federal Courthouse in Uniondale, L.I., by Raymond J. Dearie, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District; Michael R. Priore, director of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Long Island, and the District Attorneys for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, Denis Dillon and Patrick Henry, respectively.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty people, including three dentists, two lawyers, two stockbrokers and several businessmen, have been indicted on Federal charges of operating a cocaine ring that distributed as much as $5 million in sales a month, the United States Attorney's Office said today. The drug ring, whose operations were said to have stretched from Canada to California to Florida, was the ''largest known cocaine distribution enterprise'' in Philadelphia history, United States Attorney Edward Dennis Jr. said. The suspects were all believed to be part of a ring headed by a Philadelphia dentist, Dr. Lawrence Lavin, who was indicted along with 13 others in September, Mr. Dennis said. But over the last two decades, and particularly since the death of the dictator Francisco Franco in 1975, Spaniards have been casting off nearly four centuries of isolationism.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nationwide epidemic of cocaine addiction appears to have caught in its sweep women at all socioeconomic levels, ranging from those who use the drug regularly to those who use it only occasionally. More women are turning up at drug treatment centers and self- help groups looking for a way out. The motivations for using cocaine and the repercussions of its use appear in some ways to be dramatically different for women than for men. But physicians and social workers are just beginning to undertake clinical studies, and the picture of the female abuser that is emerging is often confusing. Despite the preliminary nature of these studies, and even though no one yet knows exactly how many American women are using the drug, the results indicate that cocaine abuse is a growing problem for women.

Stutman, special agent of the drug agency, said as the stood by a table piled high with plastic bags filled with white powder, which he said had a street value of $35 million. The key person arrested in the ring is a 37-year-old California resident who began smuggling cocaine while attending the University of Tennessee, Mr. Stutman said at a news conference in Manhattan. He said the operation was responsible for smuggling some 200 pounds of cocaine into the United States every month over the past 10 years. docs.lead_paragraph: CORRUPTION by Government, police and military officials is an old story in Bolivia, which has long been a primary source of the world's cocaine. During previous administrations, notably the one headed by Gen. Luis Garcia Meza in the early 1980's, the United States Embassy actively made public what it knew about the drug ties of Government and military officials. Washington saw no interest in maintaining the repressive Garcia Meza Government. Now, however, United States officials hesitate to draw attention to possible drug connections in some sectors of President Victor Paz Estenssoro's year-old Government. They support his efforts to resolve longstanding economic and political woes. And the Government has cooperated in such enforcement efforts as the recently ended operation that used United States Army helicopters to go after cocaine processing plants and clandestine shipping points.

docs.lead_paragraph: Frederick Luytjes was busy in the spring and summer of 1984. Friday evenings he would fly here from Tampa, Fla., where he was standing trial on drug-trafficking charges, and drop off his lawyer, who lived in Scranton. Then he would fly to Colombia in another plane modified to carry extra fuel and return to Pennsylvania with cocaine. The roundabout route he took, bringing in as much as 600 kilograms each trip, bypassed the Government's antidrug defenses in Florida. By Monday morning he would be back in the Tampa courtroom. Whatever the physical and emotional demands of the weekend runs to Colombia, he presented his defense -that his involvement was as a Federal informer - convincingly enough to be acquitted.

docs.lead_paragraph: A sharp rise in cocaine use among patients receiving methadone in the last year has led some drug experts to question whether the methadone programs, begun in the early 1970's to treat heroin addiction, are effective at keeping addicts drug-free. The results of drug tests regularly administered to patients in New York's methadone maintenance programs indicate that 35 percent of the people in the programs are now using cocaine. Some researchers, in fact, say methadone maintenance programs might actually increase the likelihood that former heroin addicts will try cocaine. The issue is of particular concern in New York, where the majority of state-financed programs treat addiction with methadone, an orally administered drug that stops the craving for heroin but is ineffective in treating cocaine addiction. Of 43,000 people in state-financed treatment programs in New York, 33,000 are in methadone maintenance programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: At Tory's, a rock club at 119 East 27th Street, a young man in jeans stamps out a marijuana cigarette on the bathroom floor, plucks a leather packet from his pocket and displays plastic envelopes filled with white powder. ''Grams of coke are $80,'' he says. ''My name's Joey, man. You want something, you come back to me.'' At Area, a club at 157 Hudson Street, five men and women stand in a circle in the blue shadowy light of the men's room, passing a vial and cocaine spoon from hand to hand. An attendant looks on from 15 feet away. Such scenes are not hard to find in late-night rock clubs, where cocaine use since the 1970's has been so open, institutionalized, and free from fear of management or the police that it is regarded by many New Yorkers as a convention of the city's night life.

docs.lead_paragraph: The anesthetic effect of cocaine can sensitize the brain to potentially fatal seizures induced by small amounts of the drug, according to results of tests performed on animals. Researchers at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md., said Wednesday that studies with rats show extended use of cocaine can have a ''kindling'' effect that makes the brain more sensitive to the drug. The researchers, Dr. Robert Post and Dr. Susan Weiss, said the tests indicate that the brain may be more susceptible to causing lethal convulsions from repeated cocaine use than from a single large dose, which also can cause fatal seizures.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the nation debates ways to counter drug abuse, the extent of the problem appears mixed, with statistics showing a significant increase in cocaine use but a leveling-off or decline of other illicit drugs. A new national survey expected to be made public in the next few weeks will show how drug use patterns have changed since the early 1980's. The poll, a survey of households issued by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, is coming on top of several recent national surveys showing that use of most illicit drugs except cocaine has declined in the last several years. The institute, which is the Federal agency responsible for research into drug abuse, says drug use peaked in 1979. Daily marijuana use among high school seniors, for example, is now less than half what it was in 1979, the agency says. Its last household survey on drug abuse was completed in 1982.

docs.lead_paragraph: The treatment of cocaine addiction is a fledgling field, with diverse methods being tried but too little scientific evidence of which ones work best, in the view of leading experts. The need for systematic study of different treatments has become urgent with the surge in use of crack, the experts said. Purer than cocaine powder and smoked rather than snorted, crack produces more intense highs than the powdered form, followed by more intense lows. It leads to addiction faster and in more cases. But no one knows why some cocaine or crack users become addicted, how many stop on their own or with the aid of self-help groups, and what proportion of those who enter treatment programs stay off the drug for good, said an authority on addictions, Dr. Herbert D. Kleber of Yale University.

The prosecutor, John Quinn, said that the judge's ruling would ''slightly damage'' his case against Mr. Zaccaro for drug possession but would not affect a separate charge of selling cocaine.

docs.lead_paragraph: In New Mexico last month, the authorities seized 1,184 pounds of cocaine hidden in a pickup truck. Days earlier, the police seized 700 pounds of cocaine being smuggled into Phoenix, and 1,253 pounds in West Palm Beach, Fla. In the last few weeks, law-enforcement authorities working in at least 15 states have seized more than 6,000 pounds of cocaine, nearly a month's supply for the United States. And, Bolivian authorities working with the United States Army say they have ended cocaine production in that country, at least temporarily, through raids over the last six weeks. It is estimated that these raids have cut off 20 percent to 40 percent of the United States' cocaine supply. But even with all this cocaine being kept off the American market, enforcement officials say that the price of the drug has not risen and that cocaine remains widely available on the streets.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Representative Charles B. Rangel makes a number of misstatements in his July 11 letter denouncing Louis Nizer's suggestion that government clinics, staffed by physicians, provide drugs to addicts in a controlled manner (Op-Ed, June 8). First, administering currently illegal drugs to people addicted to them would be no ''surrender to the mob,'' but rather an enormous blow to organized crime, depriving it of billions of dollars each year. It would also reduce the muggings and burglaries committed to obtain drugs, which by most estimates account for about 70 percent of such crimes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators say they have identified a 42-year-old Colombian as the largest wholesale trafficker and supplier of the cocaine industry in New York. The investigation, which over seven years has turned up networks of safe houses, millions of dollars in drugs and cash and detailed financial ledgers, has given new insights into the shadowy but giant cocaine trade in New York, they say. The Colombian, identified as Jose Santa Cruz Londono, who is a fugitive, commands a network that reaches from his bases in Cali and Bogota to the street corners of Jackson Heights and Corona, Queens, where his distributors exchange shopping bags stuffed with cocaine for bags filled with hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash, they say. The operation is so sophisticated, authorities said, that customers can buy insurance from Mr. Santa Cruz to cover costs in case a shipment is seized by the police. Armies of Dealers In addition to Mr. Santa Cruz's organization, law-enforcement officials said, at least five other Colombian cartels supply the cocaine business in New York, an industry that makes more than $10 billion a year and employs thousands of illegal aliens.

His criticism came one day after the United States Attorney, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and Senator Alfonse M. Reports from medical examiners in 25 metropolitan areas show that 185 cocaine-related deaths were reported in 1981 and 580 in 1984, and that the incomplete count for 1985 stands at 563 and is expected to go higher after all the reports are received. The compilation was made public at a news conference today. Many of those people died of heart problems as a result of cocaine use, and the Government said it issued the statistics because of the publicity resulting from the recent cocaine-related deaths of Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, and of Don Rogers, a defensive back for the Cleveland Browns football team. Both athletes were found to have died of cardiac arrest as a result of cocaine intoxication.

The illicit use of many other drugs fell by half over the period from 1980 to 1985, the survey reported. Dr. Lloyd D. docs.lead_paragraph: THE FRUIT PALACE By Charles Nicholl. 307 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95. PETER FLEMING went in search of Colonel Fawcett, A. F. Tschiffely rode the length of the Andes, Paul Theroux traveled the trains of Patagonia, and Dervla Murphy walked Pizarro's route across Peru. Such were the themes of some of South America's greatest travel writers. They seem conventional beside the Grail that inspired Charles Nicholl's journeys in Colombia - he was sent by his trendy publisher to write the Great Cocaine Story. It all started 12 years before that, when Mr. Nicholl was spending his nights in a hammock in the yard of a seedy fruit-juice parlor called the Fruit Palace in the Caribbean port of Santa Marta, Colombia. He had his first brushes with the traffic that keeps such dusty places going when a beautiful young Canadian woman lured him to a phony assignation and he found himself interpreting for a sweating gringo trying to buy five kilos of cocaine for $50,000.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cocaine can cause sudden heart death by putting rapid stress on the heart, by causing microscopic heart-muscle damage, by disrupting the central nervous system or by a combination of those effects, heart and drug experts said yesterday. Pathologists have recognized only recently that cocaine can kill by throwing the heart into an irregular rhythm, and they believe that most such deaths may be misreported simply as cocaine overdoses, in which massive depression of the nervous system can lead to cessation of breathing. Although research has intensified over the last year, scientists do not know how much cocaine is likely to cause such deaths or precisely what mechanisms are at work. ''There are sudden deaths coming into emergency rooms around the clock now,'' said Dr. Jeffrey Rosecan of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and director of the Cocaine Abuse Treatment program at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. ''I'm amazed at the tolerance some people have for cocaine, yet for others it's playing Russian roulette.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, died of intoxication from cocaine that he probably sniffed minutes before he collapsed in his dormitory room Thursday morning, the state Medical Examiner said today. Dr. John Smialek, the examiner, said the intoxication interrupted the electrical activity in Bias's brain and caused his heart to beat irregularly. ''This resulted in the sudden onset of seizures and cardiac arrest,'' he said. The findings of an autopsy report, announced this afternoon, left unanswered the question whether the death will be considered a homicide or an accident. The report was turned over to Arthur A. Marshall Jr., the Prince Georges County State's Attorney.

Mr. Bennett left Haiti shortly before Mr. Duvalier fled on Feb. 7, and United States and Haitian authorities say they do not know where he is living. docs.lead_paragraph: Drug treatment programs in New York City and its suburbs are filled to capacity and are struggling to avoid turning people away as more and more people become addicted to crack, a new and highly potent form of cocaine. The crack epidemic has spawned a debate among government officials and drug abuse experts over whether the state has done enough to cope with the highly addictive drug, whose use has spread dramatically in the last six months, particularly among teen-agers. Critics assert that New York State's system of drug treatment programs -established more than a decade ago to treat heroin addicts - does not have enough spaces or the right kind of programs to handle a new wave of crack addicts. ''The state has been outrageously neglectful in dealing with the cocaine threat and failing to provide aid to thousands of New Yorkers who need it,'' said State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican whose Committee on Investigations and Taxation has been studying the cocaine problem since 1983. ''They are fiddling while Rome burns.''

docs.lead_paragraph: As night falls on Washington Heights these days, traffic chokes to a halt on many residential streets. Hundreds of cars, some with out-of-state license plates and driven by well-dressed suburbanites, stop at street corners or double-park for a few minutes. The drivers have come to buy cocaine. At places like 174th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, drivers roll down their windows, openly pass cash to youths on the sidewalk and receive vials of the drug in return. In dozens of buildings throughout the area, the police say, legions of otherwise law-abiding citizens patronize cocaine stores operating out of apartments.

docs.lead_paragraph: In dramatically rising numbers in the last five months, teen-agers in New York City and its suburbs have been using ''crack,'' an especially potent and addicting form of cocaine, according to state and local drug officials, educators and experts on drug abuse. From the wealthiest suburbs of Westchester County to the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, drug experts and community groups say the growth of crack use has been so great that it is fast outpacing the ability of educational efforts and rehabilitation programs to cope with the problem. ''Its all over the place,'' said John French, the chief of research and evaluation for the New Jersey Health Department's alcohol, narcotics and drug abuse unit. ''There are simply not enough treatment programs to handle the demand.''

headline.main: EXTRA-POTENT COCAINE: USE RISING SHARPLY AMONG TEEN-AGERS

docs.lead_paragraph: Two New York City police officers charged with cocaine trafficking have accused 11 other officers of using cocaine, a top police official said yesterday. As a result of the allegations, 1 of the 11 has been suspended and 2 others have been transferred to new posts. While members of the department have expressed growing concern about the use of drugs by younger officers in recent years, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said recently that cocaine use by some officers was a symptom of the rising use and acceptance of the drug by society generally and does not represent a widespread problem for the department. The chief of the department's Inspectional Services Bureau, which conducted an investigation of the charges, said yesterday that the new allegations do not indicate organized drug dealing or corruption in the department. Seven members of the force of 25,800 were arrested on drug charges last year, according to the police.

docs.lead_paragraph: Half the cocaine seized in Florida late last year contained benzene, a carcinogen that has been banned from consumer products because it has been shown to cause leukemia, a Federal agency said today. ''We see the potential as extremely dangerous for lung damage or worse,'' said Robert H. Feldkamp, a spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Administration. Benzene began to show up in cocaine in early 1985 after the agency took steps to prevent illegal drug manufacturers from obtaining ether, previously a key chemical in making cocaine.

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the reality of what he had done did not sink in for several hours. Maybe that was why many hours passed before Micheal Ray Richardson confessed to the truth: He had indeed used cocaine. His admission did not come until late Tuesday evening, long after David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, announced that the 30-year-old Nets' guard had been banned from the league for testing positive for cocaine use. For most of the day, Richardson had steadfastly maintained that the test, which was taken on Monday, was erroneous. He said he had not used cocaine since his release from a drug-rehabilitation facility in Van Nuys, Calif., in January. He even submitted to another test in an effort to prove his word.

docs.lead_paragraph: Micheal Ray Richardson, the Nets' playmaking guard whose personal problems have undermined his splendid athletic talent, was banned from the National Basketball Association yesterday after testing positive for cocaine use. A grim-faced David Stern, the league's commissioner, made the announcement at a midtown hotel after the league received the results of the drug test late Monday night. The commissioner called it ''a tragic day for Micheal Ray Richardson, nothing less than the destruction by cocaine of a once-flourishing career.'' The action can be appealed after two years, and Richardson could be reinstated with the approval of the league and the National Basketball Players Association, the players' union. Charles Grantham, Richardson's agent and the executive vice president of the player's union, said that his client had denied taking drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the special care nursery at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, a 3-week-old girl squalled and twitched, her cries fitful and her limbs stiff. Lifted from the crib by Dr. Jing Yoon, the child failed to settle into the warm folds of an adult embrace - a sure sign, the doctor said, of cocaine withdrawal. In Dr. Yoon's nursery one recent afternoon eight babies were withdrawing from drugs, seven of them born to women who said they had used cocaine either alone or in combination with other toxic substances. These mothers are among the two million women who, experts estimate, regularly use cocaine. Physicians fear that many women underestimate the dangers of cocaine, and that their babies, like those of the heroin addicts who preceded them, will suffer developmental and neurological problems.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Bolivian considered by police officials to be the leading cocaine trafficker in Bolivia pleaded not guilty Monday to charges of conspiring to smuggle tons of cocaine into the United States. The Bolivian, Jorge Roca Suarez, was ordered to stand trial on Feb. 5. Also pleading not guilty and ordered to stand trial with him were his wife, Cirila Roca; two sisters, Vilma Roca and Reatriz Roca Torres, and two alleged associates, Antonia Carillo and Emilio Diaz. Mr. Roca Suarez, 38 years old, was arrested 11 days ago at his 19-room house in San Marino in Southern California, and is being held without bail. Federal Magistrate Joseph Reichmann denied a request by Sylvan Daroca, a defense lawyer, to postpone arraignment until Jan. 14 so that Mr. Roca Torres could hire another lawyer. Mr. Daroca said he had been hired only for Mr. Roca Suarez's initial court appearance Friday. A court-appointed lawyer represented Mr. Roca Suarez on Monday. John Gibbons, an Assistant United States Attorney, said Friday that Mr. Roca Suarez and 19 others were accused of sending $50 million to $60 million in drug profits to Bolivia.

headline.main: Bolivian to Face Trial In Cocaine Conspiracy
