docs.lead_paragraph: John M. Fabrizi, the mayor of Bridgeport, admitted on Tuesday that he had used cocaine and abused alcohol while in office. Mr. Fabrizi, who was appointed mayor in 2003 after the former mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, went to prison on corruption charges, said he had sought help for his drug problem about 18 months ago and that he had not used drugs since. About four months ago, he added, he stopped drinking alcohol. Mr. Fabrizi's announcement came after The Connecticut Post published an article on June 16 about the contents of an F.B.I. report that was filed earlier this month in federal court in Bridgeport. The report details interviews with a drug suspect, Juan Marrero, who talked to the F.B.I. about Mr. Fabrizi's drug use, the newspaper reported. In 2004, a Democratic Town Committee member asked Mr. Marrero for cocaine because ''Fabrizi was coming over,'' the newspaper reported. The document was quickly sealed by the United States attorney's office, which said it should never have been released.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fighting back tears, John M. Fabrizi, the mayor of Bridgeport, Connecticut's largest city, admitted on Tuesday that he had used cocaine and abused alcohol since he took office in April 2003, but said that it ''never, ever affected my job performance'' and that he had ''put this personal struggle behind me.'' His emotional admission followed months of rumors and the disclosure last week of a court document filed by federal prosecutors suggesting that he had used cocaine with a local Democratic official. The news of his problems was the latest black eye for this troubled city, whose last mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, a Democrat, was convicted on bribery, extortion and other corruption charges and is now serving a nine-year federal prison term.

Gonzales announced Wednesday. The indictment accuses the group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, of being behind 50 percent of the world's cocaine trade and 60 percent of the cocaine exported to the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two city police officers were arraigned Wednesday on charges of misconduct and falsifying records in connection with the disappearance of 11 bags of cocaine. The officers, Julio Alvarez and Sean Johnstone of the Brooklyn South narcotics unit, walked into Brooklyn Criminal Court in jeans and bulky coats, without handcuffs. They were released without bail at the request of prosecutors. Led out of the courthouse through a back exit, they left without comment.

docs.lead_paragraph: An accidental cocaine overdose caused the death of Kevin DuBrow, below, lead singer for Quiet Riot, a heavy metal band popular in the 1980s, The Associated Press reported. The announcement was made by Samantha Charles, a spokeswoman for the Clark County, Nev., coroner, after toxicology results were received on Monday. Mr. DuBrow was 52 when he was found dead in his home in Las Vegas last month.

docs.lead_paragraph: What the authorities called the largest seizure of cocaine in Mexican history -- 23 tons -- unfolded after a raid on a ship docked at the Pacific port of Manzanillo. The drug had been concealed inside two containers, one with soap and the other plastic floor tiles, the government said. The authorities were searching more containers from the Hong-Kong-registered ship, which arrived from Colombia.

docs.lead_paragraph: Navy and Coast Guard vessels were combing the coast of County Cork as more of a record haul of cocaine, estimated to exceed 1.5 tons, washed up in bales after a boat capsized. One smuggling suspect was arrested and a second man, rescued at sea, was expected to be after his release from a local hospital. The cocaine was suspected of being smuggled from South America via West Africa and bound for sale in Ireland and Britain. Cocaine is the fastest growing illegal narcotic in Ireland, where a long-booming economy is financing a wave of recreational drug use. Ireland's previous record drug seizure, in 1998, involved 660 pounds of cocaine.

docs.lead_paragraph: At least seven people -- four South Americans and three Senegalese -- have been arrested in Senegal since the seizure of 2.4 tons of South American cocaine last week, the police said, while denying that the country had become a hub for Europe-bound drugs. The Senegalese authorities confiscated more than 1.2 tons of cocaine on Sunday, in a record haul only four days after the seizure of almost the same amount of the drug near the seaside resort of Nianing, south of the capital, Dakar. The second seizure was made at a villa barely a mile from the boat where the first haul emerged.

It was the biggest seizure of narcotics in the country, the police said, and came amid concerns that the impoverished nation, with its unguarded coastline and sparsely populated interior, is becoming a major trafficking route for Latin American drug runners into Europe.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Cocaine, Hidden in Plain Sight'' by Melena Ryzik (June 10): The writer, as well as the clinical experts and club denizens she quotes, all miss a glaring truth about cocaine abuse. The legal system turns a blind eye to casual cocaine use because the users are part of an upscale, largely white, largely young population of social climbers. Crack users are perceived to be a largely poor, largely minority population with no social mobility.

headline.main: Treat Cocaine for What It Is

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, expanding its review of federal criminal sentencing, agreed Monday to consider the proper judicial response to the sharp disparity in the way the law treats crack cocaine and cocaine powder. The court will address a growing rebellion among judges who have been issuing sentences lighter than those called for under the federal sentencing guidelines for criminals convicted of crack cocaine offenses. The federal appeals courts are divided on whether judges are permitted to exercise such discretion.

headline.main: Court to Weigh Disparities in Cocaine Laws

docs.abstract: Supreme Court agrees to consider proper judicial response to sharp disparity in way law treats crack cocaine and cocaine powder; at issue is 21-year-old federal law that imposes same five-year mandatory minimum sentence for possession of 5 grams of crack as for 500 grams of cocaine powder; court will address growing rebellion among judges who have been issuing sentences lighter than those called for for criminals convicted of crack cocaine offenses; critics of disparity observe that harsh sentences for crack offenses have had disproportionate impact on black men from poor urban areas, where crack is much more common than cocaine powder favored by white users (M)
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court has agreed to consider the proper judicial response to the sharp disparity in the way the law treats crack cocaine and cocaine powder.

docs.lead_paragraph: Visitors to this city can be forgiven for thinking no place is safe here. Gunfire often echoes through the slums surrounding its port, the country's most important on the Pacific coast. As larger cities have calmed, Buenaventura has emerged as the deadliest urban center in Colombia's long internal war. Soldiers search almost every car at checkpoints on the winding road from Cali. Guerrillas recently fired mortar shells at the police headquarters. The stately Hotel Estación, a neo-Classical gem built in 1928, where executives come to hammer out deals to import cars or export coffee, is guarded by dozens of soldiers in combat fatigues.

headline.main: Cocaine Wars Turn Port Into Colombia's Deadliest City

docs.abstract: Port city of Buenaventura has emerged as deadliest urban center in Colombia's long internal war; gunfire echoes through slums and soldiers search almost every car at checkpoints on winding road from Cali; guerrillas recently fired mortar shells at police headquarters, and stately hotel where business executives come to hammer out deals is guarded by dozens of soldiers in combat fatigues; city has highest homicide rate in country; city's geography holds strategic cachet for drug traffickers; vast majority of killings are product of narrow territorial conflict over control of edge of city's slums with makeshift wharves from which fast boats depart with cocaine for points north; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: As larger cities have calmed, Buenaventura has emerged as the deadliest urban center in Colombia’s internal war.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress should repeal a law that puts first-time offenders behind bars for at least five years for possessing tiny amounts of crack cocaine, the Sentencing Commission said. Enacted during the crack epidemic of the 1980s, the law imposes the mandatory minimum sentence for possessing five grams of crack, which weighs the same as five paper clips. It takes a hundred times the amount of powder cocaine to result in the same prison term as for crack, the commission said.

docs.lead_paragraph: A veteran customs inspector recently arrested in Texas on drug charges helped traffickers smuggle about 3,000 pounds of cocaine into the country over five years, according to a court document filed last week. The inspector, Jorge A. Leija, 43, allowed smugglers to drive cars loaded with cocaine through his entry lane at the Eagle Pass border crossing, about 140 miles southwest of San Antonio, without inspection, according to testimony by an unnamed Drug Enforcement Administration agent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Along with Colombia's successes in fighting leftist rebels this year, cities like Medellín have staged remarkable recoveries. And in the upscale districts of Bogotá, the capital, it is almost possible to forget that the country remains mired in a devilishly complex four-decade-old war. But it is a different story in the mountains of the Nariño department. Here, and elsewhere in large parts of the countryside, the violence and fear remain unrelenting, underscoring the difficulty of ending a war fueled by a drug trade that is proving immune to American-financed efforts to stop it.

headline.main: Despite Rebel Losses, Cocaine Sustains War in Rural Colombia

docs.lead_paragraph: Bilma Acuña has two drug-addicted sons and roams the streets of the Ciudad Oculta slum here with a purpose: to save others from the same fate. She and the group of mothers she helps organize have become the only bulwark, it seems, against the irrepressible spread of paco, a highly addictive, smokable cocaine residue that has destroyed thousands of lives in Argentina and caused a cycle of drug-induced street violence never seen before in this country.

headline.main: Cheap Cocaine Floods a Slum In Argentina, Devouring Lives

docs.abstract: Bilma Acuna, who has two drug-addicted sons, roams streets of Buenos Aires slum trying to save others from same fate; group of mothers have become only bulwark against spread of paco, highly addictive, smokable cocaine residue that has destroyed thousands of lives in Argentina, and caused cycle of drug-induced street violence; scourge underscores significant shift in Argentina and Brazil, which have become sizable cocaine consumers; surge in drug use has been fueled by porous borders, economic hardship and rolling back of restrictions on coca growing by Bolivian Pres Evo Morales; result has been democratization of cocaine in this part of South America, which has become dumping ground for cheaper, lower-quality cocaine; map; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A highly addictive, smokable cocaine residue called paco has caused a cycle of drug-induced street violence.

docs.lead_paragraph: Since 1993, prosecutors and defense lawyers have argued over who killed Crystallynn Girard, a 13-year-old girl who was found dead in her bedroom here exactly 15 years ago. The next year, her mother, Lynn DeJac, was convicted of strangling her after a night of drinking and barhopping, and was imprisoned until last November -- when the conviction was overturned based on new evidence.

headline.main: Surprise Twist Ends Old Homicide Case: Cocaine, Not Mother, Killed Girl

docs.lead_paragraph: Among the hundreds of proposals contained in Gov. Eliot Spitzer's second executive budget, which he unveiled on Tuesday in Albany, is a provision that would impose a $3.50-a-gram tax on marijuana and a $200-a-gram tax on other illegal drugs, like cocaine.We took a look at the fine print to better understand the details of this legislative proposal -- which, incidentally, is very similar to a proposal that Mayor Edward I. Koch put forward in 1988. (That proposal, to tax illegal drugs in New York City, also at a rate of $200 a gram, did not come to fruition.)

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer has been accused of using his badge to help a friend run a cocaine-distribution operation, providing tips on which streets were lightly patrolled by officers and stealing cash from a rival drug courier in the guise of a police seizure, officials said Friday. The officer, Juan Acosta, joined the Police Department in 2000 and had been assigned to the 43rd Precinct in the Soundview section of the Bronx until his arrest Thursday. He has resigned from the force, the police said.

docs.lead_paragraph: You have probably heard the rumor that most American paper currency is contaminated with cocaine. It's not a rumor, however -- it's true. And it's even truer now. A study by Yuegang Zuo of the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth and colleagues has found that about 90 percent of banknotes contain traces of cocaine. That's up from 67 percent in a similar study two years ago.

headline.main: Those Hamiltons and Jacksons Carry Some Cocaine

docs.abstract: Yuegang Zuo of University of Massachusetts Dartmouth leads study on American currency that finds 90 percent of paper banknotes contain traces of cocaine; research, which was presented at annual American Chemical Society meeting, finds that amounts are not enough to be considered health hazard; bills from Washington, DC had highest prevalence of cocaine with 95 percent contaminated; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A study has found that about 90 percent of banknotes contain traces of cocaine.

docs.lead_paragraph: A senior Justice Department official urged Congress on Wednesday to lower the mandatory minimum prison sentence for the sale and possession of crack cocaine to match the punishment for powder cocaine, eliminating arbitrary sentencing disparities that have resulted in many more African-Americans' being jailed for longer terms. It was the first time such a high-level law enforcement official has endorsed legislation to eliminate inequities in cocaine sentencing. Barack Obama, while campaigning for the White House, had called for an end to the disparity.

headline.main: Justice Dept. Seeks Equity In Sentences For Cocaine

docs.snippet: Matching the sentence for the sale and possession of crack cocaine to that of powder cocaine would eliminate disparities that have resulted in more African-Americans being jailed for longer terms.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CRAFT FIRST surfaced like something out of a science-fiction movie. It was November 2006, and a Coast Guard cutter spotted a strange blur on the ocean 100 miles off Costa Rica. As the cutter approached, what appeared to be three snorkels poking up out of the water became visible. Then something even more surprising was discovered attached to the air pipes: a homemade submarine carrying four men, an AK-47 and three tons of cocaine. Today, the 49-foot-long vessel bakes on concrete blocks outside the office of Rear Adm. Joseph Nimmich in Key West, Fla. Here, at the Joint Interagency Task Force South, Nimmich commands drug-interdiction efforts in the waters south of the United States. Steely-eyed, gray-haired and dressed in a blue jumpsuit, he showed me the homemade sub one hot February afternoon like a hunter flaunting his catch. ''We had rumors and indicators of this for a very long period beforehand,'' he told me, which is why they nicknamed it Bigfoot.

docs.lead_paragraph: First the soldiers came to Río Seco, a coca-growing village in the lush mountain jungles of southern Peru. ''They called us subversives and they opened fire,'' said Benedicto Cóndor, 55, a coca farmer. They shot dead four people at close range, including a woman who was five months pregnant, witnesses said. Two children, ages 6 and 1, disappeared and are believed dead. Four months later, the guerrillas arrived, accusing the villagers of helping the military. They abducted the village leader, who has not been seen since.

headline.main: Cocaine Trade Helps Rebels Reignite War in Peru

docs.abstract: Rebel group Shining Path has reinvented itself as illicit drug enterprise, rebuilding on profits of Peru's thriving drug trade; military is fighting resurgent rebel faction on front lines in jungle of Vizcatan, region in Apurimac and Ene River Valley, which is nation's largest cocaine producing area; reports of rising body counts and civilians killed in cross-fire are lower than at height of Shining Path war, but are rousing memories; military burns huts in villages, claiming they are coca-leaf pits and cocaine labs; coca remains symbol of indigenous pride and is ubiquitous in region, but farmers insist they are growing it for traditional use, not drug trade, even as studies show that 90 percent of it is made into cocaine; since Shining Path retreated to region in 1992, it has melded leftist insurgency with drug running and production; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last month, President Bush touted the results of a government-sponsored study by the University of Michigan called Monitoring the Future. It reported a broad decline in drug use among young people since 2001. This included a 24 percent drop in the overall use of illicit drugs. There was one exception he said: abuse of painkillers. But, one important metric that wasn't mentioned, and that stubbornly resisted the downturn, was the use of cocaine. According to data from the group that produced the report, the percentage of both black and white 12th graders who confessed to using cocaine in the past 30 days has essentially stayed flat since 2001. The major difference is that white usage outweighs black usage 4 to 1. (If you take a longer view back to 1991, when cocaine usage bottomed out following the outrageous '80s, usage among white 12th graders since then has nearly doubled, while usage among black 12th graders has fallen a bit.)

headline.main: Cocaine and White Teens

docs.lead_paragraph: The 1986 federal drug law that punished people caught with crack cocaine far more severely than those caught with powder cocaine was a disaster on many levels. It undermined faith in the justice system by discriminating against poor and mainly minority crack users and favoring affluent white users who preferred the chemically identical powdered form. Congress tinkered at the margins of the law but failed to eliminate the sentencing disparity when it passed the Fair Sentencing Act of 2010. Now Republican lawmakers are trying to compound a longstanding injustice by opposing a proposal that would allow some people sentenced under the original law to apply for reductions in their prison terms.

headline.main: Reducing Unjust Cocaine Sentences

docs.abstract: Editorial encourages United States Sentencing Commission to ignore Republican opposition and vote in favor of allowing sentence reductions for 12,000 federal inmates who were convicted under 1986 law that punished crack cocaine possession far more heavily than powdered cocaine
docs.snippet: With disparity in punishment still on the books, the federal panel that sets sentencing guidelines should vote in favor of fairness this week.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors are warning cocaine users they may develop a painful, disfiguring skin reaction after taking the drug, because it often is mixed with levamisole, a veterinary medicine that can set off severe allergic reactions. In a paper published online June 9 in The Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology, physicians at the University of California, Los Angeles, described six patients who developed patches of purple, discolored skin after using cocaine. A few suffered permanent disfigurement to the ears, and several experienced neutropenia, abnormally low white blood cell counts.

docs.lead_paragraph: For a generation, in one of the law's gross inequities that has fallen unduly on African-Americans, 1 gram of crack cocaine was treated the same as 100 grams of powder cocaine in federal courts. It didn't matter that the theory behind the law that crack -- cocaine cooked in baking powder -- was somehow more addictive and led to more violent crime soon proved false. Congress moderated, but unfortunately didn't eliminate, that disparity last year by passing the Fair Sentencing Act of 2010, reducing the ratio to 18 to 1. For anyone, that is, who committed a crack offense after the law went into effect last August. For those who committed crack-related crimes before then but have yet to be sentenced, it doesn't. They are subject to the old mandatory minimum sentences -- 5 years for 5 grams, 10 years for 50 grams.

headline.main: Multiple Inequities: A new law lessens, but doesn't end, the sentencing disparities for crack cocaine

docs.abstract: Editorial observes that new law lessens sentencing disparities for crack cocaine, but does not end them; calls on Congress to try again and equalize penalties for possession of crack and powder cocaine

docs.lead_paragraph: The police have discovered what they said was the largest cocaine processing lab ever found in Honduras, calling it a troubling sign of Mexican drug trafficking organizations spreading into their territory. The lab was found Wednesday on a remote coffee farm in mountains 100 miles north of Tegucigalpa after a six-month investigation with the assistance of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency, said Oscar Álvarez, the security minister. It was capable of producing about a ton of cocaine a month. Honduras is a growing transshipment point for cocaine from Colombia to the United States but Mr. Álvarez said the laboratory suggested the drug, usually processed in large clandestine laboratories in Colombia, was being refined in Honduras as well. Mr. Álvarez estimated the lab had been operating for the past two or three years. No arrests were made.

China has struggled for years to prevent heroin from entering the country from Myanmar to the south, and sometimes by indirect routes from Pakistan and Afghanistan to the southwest. But experts said that other drugs were becoming a problem as well, although there had been limited evidence until now of large shipments from South America.

docs.lead_paragraph: William Mobley's life has always revolved around his family. So when he descended into the depths of an eight-year addiction to crack cocaine, it was not just his own life that he was destroying. ''Every day, I would wake up and hurt my family in a different way,'' he said, sitting in his new apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. The youngest of 12 children, Mr. Mobley, 57, has two children, four grandchildren and a great-grandson. He was born and raised in the small town of Lancaster, S.C., where he lived with a sister and his mother during his worst periods of abuse.

headline.main: Kicking Cocaine, and Reconnecting With Life

docs.lead_paragraph: Before reading this article, I was always opposed to the legalization of drugs. It seemed as though legalization would place new burdens on law enforcement and lead to unforeseen consequences. I would like to thank Patrick Radden Keefe for disabusing me of this overly simplistic view of drug policy. In his article, Keefe does a masterful job of depicting the complexity of the drug trade, showing the lengths to which the Sinaloa cartel will go to feed demand in the United States. Some form of legalization would allow these drugs to be produced more cheaply and thus cut into the cartels' profits. It would also reduce their ability to hire enforcers, bribe officials and transport their products across borders. A less muscular enemy might then give law-enforcement bodies a fighting chance. SR, Toronto, posted on nytimes.com

docs.lead_paragraph: In hip-hop circles, James Rosemond was like a prince at the royal court, whose ties to rap music's biggest stars were known far and wide. But a jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn found on Tuesday that his real job was as a drug trafficker. Mr. Rosemond was convicted of running a drug operation that sold millions of dollars' worth of cocaine, often moving it across the country in cases designed for musical equipment, a federal prosecutor said in a statement. Mr. Rosemond, widely known as Jimmy Henchman, was also convicted of financial crimes, obstruction of justice and possessing and using firearms.

headline.main: Rap Music Figure Convicted of Running Multimillion-Dollar Cocaine Ring

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Supreme Courtheard arguments on Tuesday about an aspect of one of the greatest controversies in American criminal law: the differing treatment of crack and powder cocaine. ''I've been a judge for nearly 20 years,'' said Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the only member of the current court who has served as a trial judge, ''and I don't know that there's one law that has created more controversy or more discussion about its racial impact than this one.''

headline.main: Court Weighs Revisions In Cocaine-Case Sentences

docs.abstract: Supreme Court hears arguments about the appropriate punishment for those sentenced in drug crimes involving crack and powder cocaine after a law addressing a disparity took effect in 2010; at issue is whether the new, lesser punishments for defendants caught with small amounts of crack also apply to people who committed crimes before the law went into effect, but who were not sentenced until afterward. (M)
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court heard arguments about the appropriate punishment for those sentenced in drug crimes after a law addressing a disparity took effect in 2010.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three masked man abducted the 10-year-old daughter of a convicted Bulgarian gangland boss on Tuesday, police said, in a brazen attack underscoring the Balkan country's failure to tackle rampant organised crime.

headline.main: Daughter of 'Cocaine Kingpin' Kidnapped in Bulgaria

docs.lead_paragraph: Cocaine trafficking in West Africa is being fuelled by local consumption while regional organised crime gangs are turning to methamphetamine because it is easy to make, a U.N. drug watchdog warned on Monday.

headline.main: West African Cocaine, Methamphetamine Smuggling on the Rise-U.N.

docs.snippet: Cocaine trafficking in West Africa is being fuelled by local consumption while regional organised crime gangs are turning to methamphetamine because it is easy to make, a U.N. drug watchdog warned on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Danish police say "a considerable amount" of cocaine has washed ashore along the Scandinavian country's North Sea coast but they will not release details due to an ongoing European investigation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Spanish police have seized 4.1 metric tons (4.5 tons) of cocaine with an estimated street value of €252 million ($340 million) — the biggest confiscation of the drug arriving to the nation since 2001.

headline.main: Spain Seizes 4 Tons of Cocaine Worth $340 Million

docs.lead_paragraph: Sporadic cocaine users tend to have a larger frontal lobe, a region associated with self-control, while cocaine addicts are more likely to have small frontal lobes even before they start using drugs, a new study finds.

headline.seo: Brain Shape May Play Role in Cocaine Addiction
headline.main: Brain Shape Linked to Cocaine Addiction
headline.print_headline: Neuroscience: Brain Shape Linked to Cocaine Addiction

docs.abstract: Dr Karen Ersche study in journal Biological Psychiatry suggests that people with smaller frontal lobe regions in their brains, area associated with self-control, are more at risk for cocaine addiction.
docs.snippet: Sporadic cocaine users tend to have a larger frontal lobe, a region associated with self-control, while cocaine addicts are more likely to have small frontal lobes even before they start using drugs, a new study finds.

docs.lead_paragraph: Autopsies found cocaine in the systems of two unarmed people killed by police in Cleveland after a chase that ended with 13 officers firing 137 rounds.

headline.main: Autopsies Show Cocaine in 2 Killed in Ohio Chase

docs.lead_paragraph: The 56-year-old woman said she was forced to transport $2.5 million worth of cocaine by a gang that threatened to hurt one of her children.

headline.seo: British Grandmother Sentenced to Death for Smuggling Cocaine Into Bali
headline.main: British Woman Sentenced to Death in Bali Drug Case
headline.print_headline:
Indonesia: British Woman
Is Sentenced to Die for Smuggling

docs.abstract: British government says it will protest Indonesian court ruling sentencing British citizen Lindsay June Sandiford to death by firing squad for smuggling $2.5 million worth of cocaine to island of Bali.
docs.snippet: The 56-year-old woman said she was forced to transport $2.5 million worth of cocaine by a gang that threatened to hurt one of her children.

byline.contributor: Gerry Mullany contributed reporting from Hong Kong.

docs.lead_paragraph: An Indonesian court sentenced a middle-aged British woman to death on Tuesday for smuggling cocaine worth more than $2.5 million into the resort island of Bali.
